questions.text: Which of the following is the predominant site of hematopoiesis in a 20-weeks old fetus?
questions.solution:
The liver is the predominant site of hematopoiesis in the fetus during mid-pregnancy.

Sites of hematopoiesis:

  • 2–6 weeks- yolk sac (mesoblastic phase)
  • 8–24 weeks- liver (hepatic phase)
  • 28 weeks onwards- bone marrow (myeloid phase)

Note:

There is some overlap between the different phases of hematopoiesis. The ranges given above refer to the predominant site of hematopoiesis.

questions.text: Electrophoresis and globin gene sequencing are performed on a normal embryo's blood sample as a part of hematology research. Which of the following type of hemoglobin is likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Hb Portland is likely to be present as it is embryonic hemoglobin. 


Gower-I (ζ2ε2), Gower-II (α2ε2), and Hb Portland (ζ2γ2) are called embryonic hemoglobins and are seen at 8 weeks of intrauterine life.

HbM Iwate (option A) and Hb Auckland (option C) and HbM Boston (option D) result from globin mutations that stabilize iron in the ferric state, leading to congenital methemoglobinemia.

questions.text: Hemoglobin fractions were analyzed in a neonate with a family history of sickle cell disease. The test shows elevated levels of fetal hemoglobin (HbF). Which of the following is true about HbF?

choices.text: HbF accounts for 100% of the total hemoglobin at term.
HbF is resistant to alkali denaturation.
HbF has lower affinity for oxygen than HbA.
HbF has higher affinity for 2,3 bisphosphoglycerate than HbA.

questions.solution:
HbF is resistant to alkali denaturation.

Elevated levels of HbF are seen in sickle cell disease and β-thalassemia, where there is a mutation of the β globin gene. Increased HbF levels persist in childhood and later. 

Properties of fetal hemoglobin (HbF)

  • HbF is resistant to alkali denaturation.
    • This property forms the basis of the alkali denaturation test (or Apt test) to detect the presence of fetal blood in maternal circulation in suspected feto-maternal hemorrhage.
    • The Kleihauer–Betke test (or acid elution test) is used to quantitate the amount of feto-maternal hemorrhage to calculate the dosage of anti-D required in Rh-negative mothers.
  • HBF accounts for 70% of the hemoglobin at term.
    • Increased HbF can be seen in hereditary persistence of fetal hemoglobin, sickle cell anemia, beta-thalassemia, HbC disease, and HbE disease
  • HbF has a higher affinity for oxygen.
    • This allows for gas exchange from maternal circulation by binding to oxygen at a relatively low oxygen tension in the maternal blood supplying the chorion.
  • HbF has lower  affinity for 2,3 bisphosphoglycerate (BPG) than HbA.
    • Lack of interaction between HbF and 2,3 BPG increases the affinity of HbF to oxygen.

 

The oxygen dissociation curve for HbF is shifted to the left due to increased affinity for oxygen and low 2,3 BPG levels.

questions.text: You are measuring the life span of RBCs in a normal neonate using chromium-labeled erythrocyte studies as a part of a research project under the clinical hematology department. What would be the result?
questions.solution:
The lifespan of neonatal RBCs is 60-90 days.

The short lifespan of neonatal RBCs is the cause for rapid fall in hematocrit immediately after birth. The highest hematocrit during a person’s lifetime occurs at birth, and the lowest occurs about 10 weeks later. 

The lifespan of RBCs in preterm infants is 35-50 days.

The average lifespan of RBCs in adults is 120 days.

questions.text: A concerned mother brings her preschool child to you. She states that her child was fine until yesterday night and now is covered with bruises and purple dots, which she had noticed while changing his clothes in the morning. She informs you that one month back, her child had a cough and cold. Findings on physical examination are normal, other than petechiae and purpura. Which of the following is most likely to be seen while investigating this child?
questions.solution:
An otherwise well-baby with acute onset of petechiae and purpura with a preceding history of viral infection 1 to 4 weeks prior to the onset of thrombocytopenia is a classical presentation of (autoimmune) idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura. Prolonged bleeding time is a feature of ITP.

The most common cause of acute onset of thrombocytopenia in an otherwise well-child is (autoimmune) idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP).

ITP is a bleeding disorder and has prolonged bleeding time, low platelet count, and normal coagulation profile (prothrombin time [PT] and activated partial thromboplastin time [aPTT]).

ITP has an acute presentation with a self-limited course in children.

Features of ITP:

  • Commonly affects children between 1-4 years 
  • Preceded by a viral infection
  • Mucocutaneous bleeding
  • Ecchymoses and petechiae
  • Wet purpura (blood blisters in the mouth)
  • Retinal hemorrhages
  • Bleeding into the CNS, which may be life-threatening
  • Hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy, fever, jaundice are absent
  • Resolves spontaneously in 80% of the cases in 4-6 weeks.

Laboratory features of ITP:

  • Thrombocytopenia (commonly <20,000/μL)
  • Normal/Increased megakaryocytes in bone marrow
  • Prolonged bleeding time
  • Normal tests for coagulation (PT/aPTT/INR)
  • Eosinophilia and lymphocytosis common
  • Peripheral smear is normal
  • Bone marrow biopsy shows megakaryocytes

questions.text: A pediatrician sees a child in the OPD. He has bruising, petechiae, and occasional minor epistaxis, which has very little interference with his daily activities. Based on further workup, he diagnoses the child as a case of mild ITP. How will he manage this child?

choices.text: A single dose of intravenous immunoglobulin

questions.solution:
Other than education, counseling, and watchful expectancy, no therapy is needed for patients with mild ITP. 

Classification system for ITP:

  1. No symptoms.
  2. Mild symptoms- bruising and petechiae, and occasional minor epistaxis which has very little interference with daily living.
  3. Moderate symptoms- more severe skin and mucosal lesions, more troublesome epistaxis, and menorrhagia.
  4. Severe symptoms- bleeding episodes - menorrhagia, epistaxis, and melena - requiring transfusions or hospitalization, symptoms interfering seriously with quality of life. 

Treatment of ITP:

  • Mild to moderate bleeding symptoms- watchful expectancy, education, and counseling. 
  • Platelet count < 30,000 + risk factors for bleeding (antiplatelet drugs/anticoagulants or concomitant bleeding disorders)- oral glucocorticoids/ intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) or IV anti-D
  • Severe bleeding symptoms- IV methylprednisolone ± IVIG or IV anti-D
  • Life-threatening bleeding (eg. intracranial hemorrhage)- platelet transfusion + IV methylprednisolone + IVIG or IV anti-D

Note:

The role of splenectomy in ITP should be reserved for 2 circumstances:

  1. The older child (≥4 yr) with severe ITP that has lasted >1 year (chronic ITP) and whose symptoms are not easily controlled with therapy 
  2. When life-threatening hemorrhage (ICH) complicates acute ITP and the platelet count cannot be corrected rapidly with transfusion of platelets and administration of IVIG and corticosteroids.

questions.text: Veena, an adolescent girl has had recurrent episodes of bleeding from her nose and gums. She also gives a history of heavy menstrual bleeding and repeated blood transfusions. Her bleeding time is deranged and flow cytometry reveals markedly decreased CD41 and CD61 expression. A defect in which of the following is most likely seen in her?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Glanzmann's thrombasthenia which is characterized by defective platelet aggregation.

Decreased CD41 (GPIIb) and CD61 (GPIIIa) expression are diagnostic of Glanzmann's thrombasthenia. Bleeding in Glanzmann thrombasthenia is quite severe and is typically mucocutaneous, including epistaxis, gingival, and GI bleeding.

Bernard-Soulier syndrome and Glanzmann thrombasthenia are severe congenital disorders of platelet function. Patients usually present with petechiae and purpura at birth. The diagnosis is confirmed by flow cytometric analysis of the patient’s platelet glycoproteins.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common congenital bleeding disorder?
questions.solution:
Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is the most common congenital bleeding disorder.

VWD is thought to affect approximately 0.1- 1% of the population. It is due to abnormal von Willebrand factor (VWF).

VWF is an adhesive protein that acts as a bridge between subendothelial collagen and platelets. It also binds and protects the circulating factor VIII from rapid clearance in circulation.

Von Willebrand disease is mostly inherited as an autosomal dominant trait (rarely autosomal recessive). The types of disease include quantitatively deficient vWF (partial = type 1 or absolute = type 3) or qualitatively abnormal vWF (type 2 = dysproteinemia). The majority (~ 80%) have type 1 disease. 

Hemophilia A (factor 8 deficiency) occurs in 1 in 5,000 males. Hemophilia B (factor 9 deficiency) occurs in approximately 1 in 25,000 males.

questions.text: Shortly after birth through normal vaginal delivery, a neonate develops petechiae and purpura. You suspect bleeding disorder and send samples for further workup. A prolonged bleeding time, normal platelet count, normal aPTT is seen along with large platelets in the peripheral smear. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bernard–Soulier syndrome is the likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario.

The presence of petechiae and purpura at birth, especially after vaginal delivery, along with prolonged bleeding time, normal platelet count, normal aPTT are seen in qualitative platelet defect disorders like Bernard-Soulier syndrome and Glanzmann's thrombasthenia.

The presence of large platelets rules out Glanzmann's thrombasthenia. Evans syndrome is an autoimmune hemolytic disorder with thrombocytopenia. Von Willebrand's disease doesn't usually manifest at birth. 

Bernard–Soulier syndrome is an autosomal recessive functional/qualitative platelet disorder. It is characterized by the deficiency of Gp Ib-IX receptor causing defective platelet adhesion. It is due to genetic mutations in the genes forming the GPIb complex of glycoproteins Ibα, Ibβ, V, and IX.

Laboratory parameters:

  • Normal platelet count (or mild thrombocytopenia)
  • Large platelets (megathrombocytes) with dense granules
  • Bleeding time abnormally prolonged
  • Platelet aggregation tests are normal (with collagen, adenosine diphosphate [ADP], epinephrine)
  • Ristocetin aggregation test is abnormal/no response
  • von Willebrand factor (vWF) levels are normal.

questions.text: A panicked father brings his adopted daughter to your OPD with complaints of bleeding gums. Hematological investigations reveal a normal platelet count and a prolonged bleeding time. The ristocetin-aggregation test was abnormal. Which of the following would you include in your differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ristocetin-aggregation test is abnormal in both von Willebrand disease and Bernard–Soulier syndrome.

All of the above diseases are inherited bleeding disorders affecting platelet function. Hence, there is prolonged bleeding time but platelet levels are not significantly affected. 

Platelet aggregation tests use a panel of platelet agonists (adenosine diphosphate [ADP], epinephrine, collagen, and ristocetin) to measure platelet activation and aggregation in vitro.

Ristocetin induces the binding of VWF to platelets and agglutinates platelets.

Bernard-Soulier syndrome, a severe congenital platelet function disorder, is caused by an absence or severe deficiency of the VWF receptor on the platelet membrane. Hence, in Bernard–Soulier syndrome, no response (or no aggregation) is seen with ristocetin.

The ristocetin-aggregation test is also abnormal in von Willebrand disease. However, it normalizes after the addition of normal plasma (which contains vWF) since there is no defect in binding receptors.

questions.text: An ENT surgeon refers a child who had developed prolonged bleeding post-tonsillectomy to the hematology department for evaluation. Workup revealed a qualitative defect in the von Willebrand factor. Which of the following disease is more likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of von Willebrand disease (VWD) and a qualitative defect in von Willebrand factor (VWF) is seen in type 2 VWD.

Features of VWD:

  • Most common type is Type 1
  • Most severe type is Type 3
  • Most common inheritance: Autosomal dominant
  • Type 1- partial quantitative deficiency of VWF 
  • Type 2- qualitative deficiency of VWF
  • Type 3- complete quantitative deficiency of VWF

questions.text: A pediatric resident administers 0.5-1 mg of phytonadione intramuscularly to all newborn infants in the ward. Deficiency of which of the following factors is prevented by this medication?
questions.solution:
Intramuscular injection of 0.5-1 mg of phytonadione is given to all newborn infants because it prevents the deficiency of factor VII that occurs transiently after birth.

Hemorrhagic disease of the newborn is caused by a transient deficiency of vitamin K–dependent factors, factors II, VII, IX, and X.

Causes include:

  • Lack of free vitamin K from the mother
  • Absence of the bacterial intestinal flora normally responsible for the synthesis of vitamin K.

It is responsive to and prevented by vitamin K therapy (0.5-1 mg of phytonadione).

questions.text: The most common bleeding manifestation seen in severe hemophilia is _____________.
questions.solution:
Recurrent hemarthrosis is the most common bleeding manifestation of severe hemophilia.

Hemophilia is said to be severe when the residual activity of factor VIII is <1%.

Clinical features of hemophilia:

  • Clinically, hemophilia A and B are indistinguishable.
  • It presents early in life- bleeding after circumcision or when beginning to walk or crawl.
  • Most common bleeding manifestation in severe hemophilia is recurrent hemarthrosis and the most common joint affected is the knee.
  • Acute hemarthrosis- local pain, swelling, and erythema; muscle contractures due to fixed positioning.
  • Chronic hemarthrosis- synovial thickening and synovitis in response to intraarticular blood.
  • Muscle hematomas can lead to compartment syndromes.
  • Hematuria is common but self-limited.
  • Life-threatening bleeding- bleeding to oropharyngeal spaces, CNS, and retroperitoneum.

questions.text: A grandmother has noticed that her granddaughter's umbilical stump hasn't fallen off even after 4 weeks. On examination, the pediatrician notices mild bruising. Which of the following clotting factor deficiencies should he suspect?
questions.solution:
Delayed separation of the umbilical stump beyond 4 weeks is a characteristic finding seen in factor XIII deficiency. However, these findings can also be seen in septicemia or local infections.

Factor XIII is responsible for the crosslinking of fibrin to stabilize the fibrin clot, symptoms of delayed hemorrhage are secondary to the instability of the clot. Typically, patients have trauma one day and then have a bruise or hematoma the next day.

Results of the usual screening tests for hemostasis are normal in patients with factor XIII deficiency. Screening tests for factor XIII deficiency are based on the observation that there is increased solubility of the clot because of the failure of cross-linking.
